column1: Beato Bartolomeo Pinot Grigio Superiore, Breganze DOC 2022
column2: Pinot Grigio’s heartland is in Veneto, northeast Italy. It’s where you’ll find Breganze DOC, a tiny region in the Alpine foothills which is known for prioritising quality above all else. In fact, it’s so small that the region’s growers have formed a single cooperative – Beato Bartolomeo Breganze. If Pinot Grigio is a must for your wine rack, then this one is a first-rate choice. Fresh and light, with crisp citrus flavours and floral aromas, this is Pinot Grigio at its most refreshing. Fantastic as an apéritif, but also with green salads and light fish dishes.

column1: Chosen by Majestic Valpolicella Superiore DOC 2020/21
column2: We sent our award-winning buying team all around the world on an exciting new mission: to curate a new collection showcasing the best examples of key regions and core grape varietals – at great prices. Valpolicella is loved by Majestic customers – so we went to one of the oldest cooperatives in Verona to make this benchmark wine. Located in the hills north of the city, their vines have an average age of 30-35 years old – resulting in lower yields but more concentrated flavours. A classic blend of Corvina, Corvinone, Rondinella and Molinara, this is aged for an extra year before release, adding complexity and delicious vanilla spice. It’s typically soft and smooth, with ripe notes of wild cherries. A fantastic pairing for grilled lamb chops, goulash and medium-aged cheese.
column9: Black Fruit, Red Cherry, Spice, Vanilla

column2: Pinot Noir isn’t often associated with Italy – but this famously finicky grape variety thrives in the country’s north east. In fact, it’s been grown in the Veneto region for centuries, and is even known locally as Pinot Nero. This exclusive bottling is made by Beato Bartolomeo, a cooperative based in Breganze DOC in the Alpine foothills. They’ve been making high quality wines since 1950, so they know just how to get the best out of their grapes. Cool Alpine influences keep the Pinot Noir’s flavours bright and fresh, so the team leaves the wine unoaked to let those flavours take centre stage. Discover juicy notes of strawberry and raspberry, plus soft, elegant tannins that’ll pair perfectly with charcuterie.

Grapes have been grown in Breganze DOC for more than 1,000 years. The tiny appellation lies in the foothills of the Italian Alps, and it’s here that the Beato Bartolomeo cooperative was founded back in 1950. Today, they set the standard for the region's wines. And this crisp white is a case in point. It’s made from Vespaiolo, a grape variety that’s famously used to make sweet wines – and as you’ll see in this, it makes delicious dry styles too. It’s fresh and zesty with notes of lemon and grapefruit, plus a touch of honey. The citrusy flavours make it an ideal match for fish and seafood. If you love Sauvignon Blanc but want to try something a little different, this is the wine for you.

column1: Domini Veneti 'La Casetta' Valpolicella Ripasso DOC Superiore 2019
column2: This is Valpolicella Ripasso with a difference. Ripasso wines are made by adding the leftover grape skins from Amarone production to standard Valpolicella, giving greater depth of flavour, texture and tannin. But Domini Veneti’s winemakers go a step further to make La Casetta. They re-ferment the wine with skins leftover from making Recioto – an intensely rich dessert wine – which pushes it into another dimension of flavour. Consider this an exceptional value ‘Baby Amarone’. It’s intense and spicy with rich, heady aromas. Expect notes of plum, cherry, chocolate and dried fruits. The silky texture and elegant tannins match perfectly with game dishes or roasted mushrooms.
column9: Vanilla, Fig, Red Cherry, Red Plum, Sweet Spice

column2: The Inama estate was founded in 1960. This Soave Classico is made from Garganega grown on land that was used by the Romans. This rich basaltic lava is mineral-rich and perfect for growing grapes packed with complex flavour. So you can expect ripe flavours of apricot, honey, flowers and almond. Its creamy finish lends itself perfectly to fish pie.

This complex Italian rosé first hit our shelves in small, limited supply. Our customers loved it so much, we soon went back for more. It’s made by Pasqua, a historic family-run winery who are behind some of our best-selling bottles. So you can be sure you’re in for something delicious. It’s made from Corvina, Trebbiano, Syrah and Carménère grapes, which all thrive in Pasqua’s beautiful Veneto-based vineyards. Its name comes from the length of time the juice is left on the grape skins – exactly 11 minutes, the perfect amount of time to give the wine its delicate rosy colour. It's elegant and subtly spicy, with plenty of red-fruit flavours. Transport yourself to Italy by pairing it with baked white fish, olives and tomatoes.

Pasqua are behind a number of our best-selling wines. We stocked their '11 Minutes' rosé a few years ago, and it was immensely popular with Majestic customers. They've just made it even better. So it was a no-brainer for our rosé buyer, to pick this up. It's made from Corvina, Trebbiano and Carménère grapes and partially fermented in oak. Sounds familiar? Not to many. But this is a recipe for something remarkably complex, fresh, structured and elegant. Try its flavours of red fruits, citrus and vanilla with grilled fish.

This is one of our most popular Italian reds. It’s fantastically plush and full of flavour – all thanks to the ‘appassimento’ style of winemaking. This means the grapes are picked at the peak of their ripeness and left to dry in special crates until they’ve lost 30% of their volume. It concentrates all the sugars and flavours in the grapes, making the texture seriously lush and velvety. With this intensity you won’t believe the price. Think stewed plum, blackberry and juicy cherry flavour, with notes of violet and heady sweet spice. It’s fantastic with meat ragù piled over pasta.

Think ‘appassimento’, you'll most likely think Amarone – or other really plush reds. It’s a method of making wine with a portion of dried grapes, concentrating all the flavours and giving it a real richness of texture. But this wine is a little different. For a start, it’s white – and every single part of its production is designed to make it richer and more intensely flavoured. The grapes are left to dry in special racks, concentrating the sugars and aromas. After it’s pressed the wine is left on its skins to make the texture rounded and the flavours bolder. Finally, a portion is aged in oak for added creaminess. No wonder it’s a beast of a wine. Bold. Fruity. Plush. There’s a lovely balance of fresh citrus flavours and apricoty, peachy richness. Delicious with roast chicken.

Love Amarone but don’t want to break the bank? Valpolicella Ripasso is for you – it’s even nicknamed ‘baby Amarone’. It’s made in a clever way which melds the fresh fruitiness of standard Valpolicella with the rich, bitter-chocolatey character of Amarone. How do they do it? The clue is in the name: Ripasso. It literally means to ‘re-pass’ – the method of re-fermenting normal Valpolicella wine with the leftover skins from Amarone production. It transforms the standard light-bodied Valpolicella into a soft, supple, full-bodied wine which is seriously moreish. Morello cherries. Blueberries. Liquorice. It’s lush and ripe with a touch of dried fruitiness from the Amarone skins. Perfect with roast lamb
column9: Vanilla, Fig, Red Cherry, Red Plum, Sweet Spice

column1: Tommasi 'Il Sestante' Amarone della Valpolicella DOCG 2017/18
column2: Tommasi have prime sites in some of Valpolicella's best hillside vineyards. It's on these that they produce dazzling and award-winning Amarone. Their signature style is elegance over power. They've come up trumps again with the Il Sestante. Expect a full-bodied palate, smooth tannins and intense aromas of ripe cherries and plums. Decant for at least an hour and serve at room temperature with hard cheeses.

column1: Masi 'Costasera' Amarone della Valpolicella Classico DOCG 2017/18
column2: This is produced by Masi – a byword for quality in Italian winemaking. Amarone is one of the most regulated DOCGs in Italy. Producers aren’t even allowed to pick their grapes until they’re given official word – so it takes special determination to go above and beyond in pursuit of quality. Masi make it look effortless. Their grapes are dried on special bamboo racks, then fermented for an extraordinary eighty days – about double the standard time – and matured in Slovenian oak. Masi call this their gentle giant – it's beautifully elegant and bold. Discover rich, dark-fruit flavours, with hints of coffee, cocoa and spice. Perfect for strong cheese like Gorgonzola.
column9: Vanilla, Chocolate, Fig, Red Cherry, Red Plum, Sweet Spice

column2: Domini Veneti have been a firm favourite of Majestic customers for many years. They’re best known for their ‘La Casetta’ Valpolicella Ripasso, but this white blend of Garganega, Trebbiano and Chardonnay grapes is a head-turner in its own right. Produced from grapes grown on volcanic soils in the heart of the Soave Classico region, Domini Veneti pour over 30 years of experience into every bottle. You’ll find notes of blossom, citrus and pineapple, plus a creamy texture that pairs well with seafood dishes. Try it with salmon ceviche.
column9: Blossom, Citrus Fruit, Pineapple, Tropical Fruit

column2: The Boscaini family have owned and run Masi for six generations, and are one of Veneto's most well established producers. This delicious wine goes through a second fermentation process with partially dried grapes. The result is a velvety-smooth complex red comparable to plush Amarone wine – without the price tag. Wine critic James Suckling awarded the 2018 vintage an impressive 91 points. Expect intense notes of ripe cherry with hints of tobacco, vanilla and cinnamon spice. Enjoy it with a cheese and charcuterie platter.

Known for their timeless quality, Pieropan have been producing incredible wines in Veneto since the 1890s – and they were the first to use the Soave name on their bottles. The family has been at the forefront of innovation, popularising the use of French barriques for fermentation and ageing. And fourth-generation Dario Pieropan is no different. His adventurous nature has led him to explore the production of a duo of red wines from his family estate in Valpolicella. This silky red is crafted from just eight hectares of vines, spending between 18-24 months ageing in large oak barrels and further ageing in bottle at the estate. And, like all Pieropan wines produced since 2015, it's certified organic. Expect a soft and smooth wine, with complex flavours of red cherry, wild strawberry, and hints of spice. It’s an ideal match for roasted pork dishes.

column1: Beato Bartolomeo Pinot Grigio Rosato 2021/22, Delle Venezie
column2: The Alpine foothills tumble down into the Veneto in North-Eastern Italy. It’s here you’ll find the tiny Breganze DOC. It’s so small that the region’s 700 growers have formed a single cooperative: Beato Bartolomeo Breganze. They make so little of this delicious rosé that we buy everything they make. It’s incredibly bright and fruity with really delicate flavours. Peach. Apricot. Raspberry. It’s delicious with light salads.

column1: Allegrini Amarone della Valpolicella Classico DOCG 2017/18
column2: Amarone is one of Italy’s most celebrated wines. Hailing from the Valpolicella region, it’s made from Corvina grapes that have been partially dried before crushing. This makes for concentrated dried-cherry aromas and a distinctly rich, powerful wine. Allegrini’s version, made in the heart of the prestigious Vapolicella Classico sub-region, strikes a happy balance between modernity and tradition. Expect intense notes of ripe dark fruit and spice. Try it with a fillet steak or Italian-style braised beef stew.
column9: Vanilla, Chocolate, Fig, Red Cherry, Red Plum, Sweet Spice

column1: Cantina Negrar 'Vigneti di Roccolo' Amarone della Valpolicella 2019/20
column2: Barolo, Brunello and Amarone are the three kings of Italian wine. But while Barolo and Brunello have been around for centuries – even millennia – Amarone has only existed since 1938. How has it reached equal renown so quickly? In short: Amarone is unique. It’s made using dried grapes. That’s standard practice for sweet wines. as it reduces the water volume in the grapes, upping the percentage of sugar. But Amarone ferments the grapes to dryness, meaning it’s got a lot of alcohol, a lot of viscosity – and a lot of flavour. It makes for a seriously opulent wine. Plush. Layered with both fresh and dried-fruit flavours. There really is nothing quite like it. Fantastic with braised meat and aged cheese like Parmesan or Pecorino.
column9: Vanilla, Chocolate, Fig, Red Cherry, Red Plum, Sweet Spice

column2: The Definition range brings the world's greatest wine styles to Majestic customers. To capture the essential elements of Valpolicella Ripasso, we went to a family that's made wine in the region for 108 years. Rich and spicy, with notes of cherry, tobacco and black pepper. Serve with chargrilled steak.

This is a remarkable example of why Soave Classico is a whole different sip from what you'll find from the Soave crowding supermarket shelves. The Pieropan estate was the first to ever make single-vineyard Soave. Today, they make this organic expression on the hillsides in the heart of the Soave Classico area. Left on texture-building lees, it's fresh and expressive with notes of white flowers, almond and marzipan, a fresh, clean acidity and hints of pastry on the finish.
column9: Stone Fruit, Citrus Fruit, Honey, Quince

column2: Italian Pinot Grigio is a classic for a reason – it’s the ultimate light, crisp white. Perfect for everyday and versatile enough to work in any situation, with almost any food. But we didn’t want to settle for just any old wine. We challenged our buyers to find the very best wine they could at this price point. And they don’t do things by halves. They tasted more than fifty Pinot Grigios before they settled on this as the very best quality for the money. We think they hit the nail on the head. It’s citrussy. It’s peachy. It’s got lovely crisp apple flavours – and it’s really refreshing. All you could want from an Italian Pinot Grigio. Of course, it’s a great party wine, but it’s also perfect with light salads and fish.

Red wine is a go-to for winter warming and Negrar Il Viaggo Appassimento leaves no trace of doubt as to why. It's rich in texture, deep and plummy with uplifting notes of red cherry and violet that perfectly round the palate. Enjoy with rich red meat dishes, such as aged beef and venison.

Each bottle in our Selected by Majestic range has been chosen by our award-winning team of buyers for its unmistakable value and instantly enjoyable taste. In this Fizzy & Juicy wine, you can expect fresh flavours of red apple and ripe summer berries, with soft bubbles. A fantastic apéritif.

column1: Cantina del Garda Valpolicella Ripasso DOC 2019
column2: The timeless, elegant wines of Cantina del Garda match their wonderfully ornate labels, which evoke the classic design style of Verona. They produce a range of impressive wines that capture the character of the northern Italian region, including a Soave, Corvina and Italy’s favourite sparkling – Prosecco. It doesn’t get much more classic Valpolicella Ripasso than this. Crushed Corvina Veronese, Corvinone, Rondinella and Molinara grapes are combined with the partly fermented skins from Amarone wine production. This creates a bottling that’s a beefy step-up in body, flavour and tannin from standard Valpolicella. Expect intense cherry aromas and full-on flavour.
column9: Black Cherry, Black Pepper, Sweet Spice

column2: Each bottle in our Selected by Majestic range has been chosen by our award-winning team of buyers for its unmistakable value and instantly enjoyable taste. Fizzy & Fruity is made predominantly from Glera – Prosecco's star grape – so fans of Veneto's signature sparkling are in for a real treat. Expect notes of fresh citrus, ripe apple and peach, with soft, creamy bubbles.

Celebrated for producing some of Italy's finest whites, the Soave Classico DOC surrounds the medieval village of Soave in the breezy Alpine foothills of Veneto. The Romans were the first to plant Garganega vines here – now the primary grape of this iconic region. And this expressive wine is your chance to taste the style at its finest. It's crafted by Domini Veneti, an old time Majestic favourite and the name behind our ever popular ‘La Casetta’ Valpolicella Ripasso. Grapes are sourced from the Foscarino subregion – one of a select few premium sites granted ‘cru’ status. Vines here are planted around three now-inactive volcanoes where nutrient-rich slopes provide perfect conditions for fascinating, age worthy wines. Expect a distinctive mineral character with complex notes of elderflower, peach and a subtle almond nuttiness. A refreshing acidity makes this the perfect wine to accompany a variety of fish dishes.

column1: Pasqua ‘Mater Anna’ Rosé 2021/22, Delle Venezie DOC
column2: The Mater Anna is a single-vineyard rosé wine made from a strict selection of Pinot Grigio grapes in the beautiful Matteranetta vineyard in Verona. The result is a fresh and well- balanced wine that stands out with its floral notes, which meld with hints of peach and apricot.

With Pinot Grigio rosé in huge demand, quality can be patchy as some producers try to keep up. Bardolino Chiaretto offers a top quality alternative from a region already recognised for its fantastic reds. Made by customer favourite producer Pasqua on the shores of Lake Garda, this is the perfect rosé for summer. At just 12%, it's fresh and elegant, with youthful notes of cherry, raspberry and strawberry.

Pieropan are the biggest name in fantastic Soave. They were the first producer to label wines with the Soave name back in the 1930s and continue to fly the flag for the region today. Their organic wines have a signature richness and zest. This one is from a single vineyard, La Rocca, where limestone soils produce distinctly rich and opulent wines. It has aromas of almond and honey and flavours of ripe apricot and exotic fruit. Try it with seafood linguine.

Although located around 100km west of Treviso, the romantically inspiring city of Verona is where Pasqua was founded in 1925, as well as having provided the backdrop for Shakespeare's Romeo & Juliet. Pale salmon in colour, fresh on the nose with notes of pear and red fruits. On the palate it is dry with hints of red fruits and refreshing acidity.

Pinot Grigio only came to Sicily in the past couple of decades. It’s usually thought of as a northern Italian grape – but it’s taken to its new island home like a duck to water. This organic Pinot Grigio was lovingly made by Frederico ‘Fede’ Stella – a gentle giant who knows how to coax the very best from his grapes. The grapes come from twenty-five-year-old vines, and each and every one is handpicked in the cool of dawn to make sure as many of the aromatics are preserved as possible. All that work pays off. It’s a deliciously crisp wine, full of citrusy zing. But thanks to Sicily’s warm climate, it also has riper, peachy flavours and fragrant, herby aromas. Delicious with freshly caught seafood.

Mount Etna is an iconic feature of the Sicilian landscape. It’s one of the world’s most active volcanoes and has been a UNESCO World Heritage Site since 2013. Its highly fertile soils make it a prime spot for agriculture – and it’s here that Torre Mora grow their grapes. They make this wine from two local varieties, Nerello Mascalese and Nerello Cappuccio. Its name, ‘Cauru’, means ‘hot’ in Sicilian – a reference to the heat and energy contained in the volcanic soils. This heat makes for intense, ripe flavours, but the wine is also remarkably fresh thanks to the region’s drastically cooler nighttime temperatures, which help retain the grapes’ natural acidity. Discover vibrant notes of raspberry and violet, with jammy cherry flavours and fine, silky tannins. You can also expect a distinct savoury character that makes this an ideal accompaniment to richer poultry, mushroom-based dishes and mature cheeses.
column9: Citrus Fruit, Date, Raspberry, Red Cherry, Violet, Pomegranate

column2: Revered winemaker Stefano Chioccioli is the brains behind one of our most-loved reds, the Nero Oro. But if you spend just a little extra, you can unlock Stefano’s full arsenal of winemaking tricks with the Nero Oro Riserva. Taken from his best vineyards and aged for 18 months in oak, it’s closer to a rich Amarone than its island home would suggest. Expect bold damson, blackcurrant and dried-fig notes, with a rich oak spice. The plush fruity flavours make it a delicious pairing for juicy beef burgers.
column9: Vanilla, Black Plum, Blackberry, Cedar, Fig, Sweet Spice

column2: If your idea of a good red is velvety-smooth and full of plush fruit, our top-selling Nero Oro is not to be missed. So what makes it so silky-smooth? Creator Stefano Chioccioli uses the appassimento style of winemaking. After picking, his grapes are left to dry out in the warm sun, adding richness and intensity. Dessert wines have been made this way in Sicily for centuries, but the dry Nero Oro is something entirely unique – and you’ll only find it at Majestic. It’s full-bodied with concentrated flavours of cherry, damson and blackcurrant. Its silky texture makes it a great match for aubergine-based pasta.
column9: Vanilla, Black Plum, Blackberry, Sweet Spice

column2: With its sun-drenched landscapes and moderate rainfall, the Mediterranean island of Sicily is a prime place for organic grape-farming. And the young winemaker behind this bottle, Marco Lachemet, knows how to make the most of it. Set between 200 and 450 metres above sea level, his organic vineyards have shown to be perfect place for growing fruity Nero D’Avola, Sicily’s trademark red grape. This is bright and packed with red-berry aromas. It's smooth, fresh and incredibly drinkable. You’ll love it with meat dishes, such as ox-cheek ragù.

It’s very unusual to find a white wine made appassimento-style. That’s what makes this plush Sicilian white so exciting. It’s made by drying a portion of grapes on the vine and a portion in the sun. This method is best known for making decadently rich reds, like Amarone. But this, an appassimento Grillo, is something entirely new. Grillo is a wonderfully aromatic and distinctly Italian white grape. It’s the perfect base for this style of winemaking. Honeyed and full of dried-fruit notes, this has the fresh zing of grapefruit. Not to mention, it’s delicious with Moroccan-spiced rice dishes.

column1: Caruso & Minini 'Corte Ferro' Nerello Mascalese-Frappato 2021/22, Sicily
column2: Caruso & Minini are one of the producers defining Sicily's wine revolution. From an estate 400 metres above sea level in the remote west of the island, they concentrate on reviving local varieties. This blend of light-bodied Frappato and more tannic Nerello Mascalese, is a red truly unique to Sicily. It's snappy and full of wild berries, spices and refreshing acidity that'll delight fans of Beaujolais or Cabernet Franc.

Light wines from local grapes Grillo, Inzolia and Cataratto are fortified with white grape spirits in the traditional way. The Marsala Fine is dry in style and has all the characteristics of good Marsala with notes of toasted almonds, citrus and caramel.

Planeta began with a dream to put Sicily on the world map. But how do you convince the naysayers? You speak their language - Chardonnay. This is now a Sicilian icon that's enjoyed the world over. So it's fair to say they nailed the brief. It's rich and creamy, with notes of yellow peach, honey, toast and marzipan. Fantastic lightly chilled with turkey.

Planta is one of Sicily's great wineries. It played a large part in boosting the region's reputation for fine wines. And this one is particularly interesting. The winemaking team first began experimenting with Fiano in the 1990s and, after much deliberation, created their finest expression of the grape: Cometa. It's complex and intense, with aromas of chamomile, thyme and mango, flavours of apricot, almond and basil and a long finish. Try it with grilled snapper.

Stefano Chioccioli is the man behind Nero Oro, one of our bestselling reds. He’s made wine in almost all of Italy’s regions and his skill is obvious – Robert Parker has scored several of his wines at 100 points. So it’s no surprise that our buyers were impressed with this rosé. It’s made from Nerello Mascalese – a grape native to Sicily. It’s not often made as a single variety wine, making this a pretty unique bottle. Discover pretty notes of rose, violet and wild summer berries. A streak of minerality makes it really fresh and elegant, so it’s a perfect choice for light summer salads topped with grapes, strawberries or watermelon.

column1: Alluria Pinot Grigio Organic Boxed Wine 2.25L, Sicily
column2: Pinot Grigio only came to Sicily in the past couple of decades. And it’s taken to its new island home like a duck to water. This organic Pinot Grigio was lovingly made by Federico Stella – a gentle giant who knows how to coax the very best from his grapes. These grapes come from 25-year-old vines, and they're handpicked in the cool of dawn to preserve the aromatics. All that work pays off. It’s a deliciously crisp wine with a moreish citrusy zing. But thanks to Sicily’s warm climate, it also has riper, peachy flavours and a fragrant, herby aromas. Delicious with freshly caught seafood.

Our mission was to find the best tasting wines at £5.99.  So we blind tasted 500 wines and chose the best irrespective of grape variety or country. Crisp and thirst quenching with exuberant red berry flavours that are best enjoyed ice cold.

Made from local grape varieties on an estate owned by the noble Tasca family since the 1830s. Delicate but not bland, fruit flavours of apple, peach and pink grapefruit are to the fore of the crisp and refreshing wine. Best with shellfish, fish or vegetarian dishes.
column9: Peach, Citrus Fruit, Grapefruit, Green Apple

column2: Love big, bold reds? If so, you’ve likely tried Californian Zinfandel or Italian Primitivo. These sibling grapes may be genetically identical, but each has its own distinct character. And this velvety bottling combines the best of both. It’s a classic, earthy Primitivo with a modern twist inspired by the smooth, plush character of Zinfandel. The grapes are macerated in their own juice before fermentation, which dials up the delicious fruity flavour. And six months of oak ageing gives it extra complexity and a silky texture. Discover notes of cherry, plum, coffee and cocoa, plus hints of black pepper and vanilla spice. It’s the perfect partner for rich tomato-based dishes.

In the heel of Italy's boot, you’ll find Puglia – the home of Primitivo. But this particular bottling is anything but ordinary for the region. It’s made using the appassimento method, which has been a distinctly northern Italian style of winemaking for centuries. Primo’s winemaker, Alessandro Michelon, was the first outside of Veneto to adopt the method. He realised that Puglia’s sun-drenched, windswept vineyards offer an ideal climate for the process; once grapes are ripe, his team move through the vines, twisting the stem of every other bunch. This stops them from ripening further and allows them to dry in the wind, resulting in a concentrated and complex wine. Just like a Valpolicella, it’s big, plush and velvety, with ripe flavours of cherry, raspberry and redcurrant. A rich, meaty stew makes the perfect partner to its bold, fruity character.

column1: Surani 'Costarossa' Primitivo di Manduria DOC 2021/22, Puglia
column2: If you love ripe, bold reds then this is an absolute must-try. We think Puglia is underrated. It’s right in the heel of Italy’s boot – and you’d be forgiven for thinking the sun-baked vines could never produce a wine as silky and soft as this. But it’s precisely that heat that Primitivo loves. The grapes are left on the vines until they’re almost overripe – giving the flavours incredible concentration. Intense. Velvety. Ripe. It’s full of plummy, red-fruit flavour with moreish spice. Ageing in oak for a year gives it an extra dimension of flavour, smoothing the plush tannins. With a distinctly Italian hint of woody herbs, it's ideal with pasta dishes.

Rivera, the big name behind the TerraAnima brand, has been a benchmark for quality in Puglia since the 1980s. They’ve driven a new appreciation for the region’s wines both across Italy and around the world, and are committed to farming native grape varieties. There’s a continual push to improve quality while still respecting the natural process. It might be sun-baked southern Italy, but Puglia’s geography allows it to produce fabulously fresh white wines as well as hearty reds. This fruity combo of Bombino Bianco and early-harvest Chardonnay is made from grapes plucked from hillsides in the region’s centre.
column9: Citrus Fruit, Fig, Herbal, Stone Fruit

column2: Fiano is the Italian grape that rewards the adventurous white-wine fan. The Surani estate is just four miles from the Ionian coast. It's heavily inspired by its Ancient Greek heritage. And this is their trademark Fiano. It's textured and floral, with notes of honey and nuts. Sea breezes bring a gentle layer of minerality to this complex white. Enjoy it with creamy and rich pasta dishes.
column9: Tropical Fruit, Citrus Fruit, Floral, Melon

column2: Puglia, Italy’s heel, is the ideal region for great Primitivo. It thrives in the warmth here and the bright sunshine helps perfectly ripen its thick skins. Crisp sea breezes refresh the vines,  giving the grapes plenty of time on the vine and letting flavours develop slowly. This is made by a family winery that has over a century of winemaking history since it was founded in 1910 – so you know you’re in for something great. It’s rich and bold with flavours of black fruits and Mediterranean herbs with a spicy finish. It’s perfect for rustic pasta or Pizza with 'Nduja.

Our store managers know Majestic customers best. Which is why once a year we task them with selecting a wine they know you'll love. In 2018, they overwhelmingly chose this. Indulge in an intense palate of blackcurrant and wild bramble fruit, elevated by charming hints of thyme and sweet spice.

The sun-kissed region of Puglia is the perfect setting for growing Primitivo grapes. It was first brought to Manduria, on the heel of Italy’s boot, back in 1881 by Countess Sabini di Altamura as part of her dowry. And now the region is renowned for its deep, velvety wines. This organic expression has fantastic intensity, and since it hasn’t had any oak ageing, it’s all about juicy fruit flavour. Expect aromas of blackberry, cherry and violet and a long, smooth finish. Try it with braised meats or hard cheeses.
column9: Sweet Spice, Black Cherry, Red Fruit

column2: The family behind Paolo Leo winery have been making wine since the 18th century. So they know a thing or two about getting the best out of the Puglian soil. Their passion for Italy is reflected in the fact they choose to farm organically. We think the fruit really stands out as a result. In certainly shows in this blend of Chardonnay, Fiano and Sauvignon Blanc, with its rich notes of tropical fruit and citrus acidity. Pair with delicate white fish.

column1: Vigneti del Salento ‘Zolla’ Primitivo di Manduria DOC Riserva 2017
column2: The Farnese Group was founded in 1994 with the aim to be leaders of a renaissance in Italy's wine scene. 200 gold medals and countless accolades later, and they've been named Italian Producer of the Year four times. It's safe to say they've achieved their goal. This wine is sourced from their vineyards, where low-yielding vines ripen intensely flavoured grapes. The naturally dark-skinned Primitivo grapes give this wine a deep, inky colour, and ageing for 12 months in French oak has given it a rounded structure. If you like our Surani Primitivo, this is a great next step. Expect notes of violets, blackberries and cherries in each sip. This will pair well with mature cheeses, like Pecorino Toscano.

The looming Monte Vulture may look like an intimidating place to make wine, but it hasnt erupted for thousands of years, and and it's now where you'll find some of Italy's most impressive soils. Here, the late-ripening Aglianico grape thrives on volcanic vineyards, and this resulting wine is one of Italy's hidden gems. It's very well structured, with notes of dark fruits and black pepper. It will develop excellently over time and pairs fantastically with Mediterranean dishes.

The Pasqua name is synonymous with quality – and a firm favourite with Majestic customers. Their winemaking story began almost a century ago, when the first generation of the Pasqua brothers established a business in Verona devoted to the trade of wines from their homeland, Apulia. It’s here on Italy’s heel that this rich and textured wine is made. It’s an addition to the much-loved ‘Desire, Lush and Zin’ range – so we just had to bring this blend of Chardonnay and Fiano to our shelves. Expect ripe notes of lemon, peach and orange with light floral hints. Its rich texture makes it an ideal pairing for creamy chicken dishes.

The Pasqua name is synonymous with quality – and a firm favourite with Majestic customers. Their winemaking story began almost a century ago, when the first generation of the Pasqua brothers established a business in Verona devoted to the trade of wines from their homeland, Apulia. It’s here, on Italy’s heel, that this incredible rosé is produced. Going back to their roots, Pasqua blend Primitivo, Negroamaro, Syrah and Chardonnay grapes that benefit from the warm southern sun and produce a ripe and expressive style of rosé. It’s remarkably aromatic and perfumed, with aromas of dried herbs and intense flavours of red and black fruits. Pronounced fruit flavours make it a perfect match for pasta in tomato sauce or pizza.

A lot of Italian Chardonnay sits nicely nestled between Old World and New World styles. They can be a little more generous with ripe-fruit flavour, while retaining as much elegance as a classic white Burgundy. If you’ve never tried one before, you can put your trust in one of Veneto’s most renowned wineries to deliver something fantastic. Founded in 1925, Pasqua has a wealth of heritage and winemaking expertise. This third-generation Veronese estate was built on a love of Valpolicella, the region’s signature red. But as this white wine goes to show, it’s not all that they’re good at. Made in a distinctly Burgundian style, this Chardonnay has flavours of stone fruit, hazelnut and vanilla. Try it with your favourite creamy pasta dish.

Grego di Tufo is one of Southern Italy’s most coveted white wine regions. Its rich, volcanic soils, high-altitude vines and distinct temperature variations encourage a mineral, elegant style of wine. This bottle has been crafted by one of Italy's most dynamic and talented winemakers, Alessandro Michelon. So you can expect excellence. It’s perfumed, tropical and refreshing – expect hints of mango, pear and fresh herbs. Delicious with fresh mozzarella.

column1: Feudi di San Gregorio Greco di Tufo DOCG 2021/22
column2: Feudi di San Gregorio was founded in 1986, after a devastating earthquake destroyed much of the local area. It’s since become a beacon for the wine renaissance of Southern Italy. Greco di Tufo is one of the region’s most prestigious white wines where it thrives on volcanic soils, developing a delicious minerality. During the winemaking, the wine is left to rest on the spent yeast cells, or lees, for eight months to add extra texture. Expect an elegant, bright and citrusy wine with hints of almond. Its ripe flavours and freshness make it an excellent pairing for a simple spaghetti alle vongole.
column9: Grapefruit, Honey, Lemon, Peach, Red Apple

column2: One of Italy's great unsung white wines. Three months' lees ageing before bottling imbues the wine with added depth and texture, but no oak is used, so the wine retains a light and fruit-driven character. A brilliant all-rounder, with plenty of citrussy fruit and faint notes of apple and quince, with the merest hint of nutty complexity. The balance of crispness and texture means this accompanies a huge range of foods, from roasted vegetables to fish and poultry.

Piccini are one of Italy’s most dynamic and innovative producers. Now in their fourth generation of family ownership, they have over 140 years of expertise behind them. Their roots lie in Tuscany – and today they’re considered one of the region’s leading wineries. This aromatic white blend combines two traditional Tuscan grape varieties, Vermentino and Malvasia. It spends seven weeks maturing in special clay amphorae, which gives it an elegant texture while still allowing the fruit flavours to take centre stage. Discover notes of white flowers, orange peel and tropical fruits with a touch of spice and gentle minerality. These complex flavours make it an excellent match for fish and seafood dishes.

Piccini are one of Italy’s most dynamic and innovative producers. Now in their fourth generation of family ownership, they have over 140 years of expertise behind them. Their roots lie in Tuscany – and today they’re considered one of the region’s leading wineries. This vibrant blend combines two classic Tuscan grape varieties, Sangiovese and Malvasia Nera. It spends 12 weeks maturing in special clay amphorae, which gives it an elegant texture while still allowing the fruit flavours to take centre stage. Expect delicate floral aromas alongside fresh cherry and red-berry flavours. Its soft tannins and long, fruity finish make it the perfect pairing for red meats or aged cheeses.

column1: Agostina Pieri Brunello di Montalcino DOCG 2017/18
column2: Brunello di Montalcino is one of Italy's finest red wines. And this is made by Agostina Pieri: a small family winery that consistently provides great value in an otherwise expensive region. It's full-bodied and silky, with flavours of red and black fruits, basil and mint. Decant this for at least an hour and serve at room temperature with a hearty sirloin steak. Or if you can wait, it will develop for another seven years.

Piccini are one of Italy’s most dynamic and innovative producers. Now in their fourth generation of family ownership, they have over 140 years of expertise behind them. Their roots lie in Tuscany – and today they’re considered one of the region’s leading wineries. So you can expect great things from this. A Tuscan icon, Brunello di Montalcino is one of the finest expressions of the Sangiovese grape, famed for its bold, complex and full-bodied character. Piccini capture all those qualities here – and the stunning 2018 vintage won them a gold medal at The Drinks Business's 2023 Global Sangiovese Masters awards. Discover intense flavours of black cherry, blueberry, spice and liquorice, with silk-smooth tannins and a long, elegant finish. Its excellent structure makes it a fantastic pairing for rich game meats or mature cheeses.

Ornellaia is an estate in demand. Their first wine is one of the most sought-after in Italy. ‘Le Volte’ is your chance to taste their expertise at a lower price, and it favours the adventurous. Here, Sangiovese is combined with Merlot and Cabernet Sauvignon. It's an exciting twist on the Super Tuscan blend. Aged for over 10 months in oak, it has great structure, fresh notes of red fruits and a balancing acidity that are sublime with venison.
column9: Vanilla, Black Fruit, Red Fruit, Tobacco

The Cecchi family has a rich Tuscan history. And today they adopt an 18th-century winemaking method to make this a rich, fruity style of Chianti. Made primarily from Sangiovese, this is a smooth wine with notes of ripe red fruits and a balancing acidity. Excellent with mushroom pasta.
column9: Sweet Spice, Black Cherry, Red Fruit

Francesco Giuntini is one of the most respected winemakers in Chanti Rufina. He now crafts this organically, and it goes a long way to show why Chianti Rufina is well worth looking out for. This is a perfumed, elegant red with fine-grained tannins, flavours of dark cherries and spice and a freshness on the finish.

column1: Castello di Meleto 'San Pietro' Chianti Classico DOCG 2020/21
column2: The first mention of Castello di Meleto dates back to the 13th century. But it wasn't until the 1960s that the castle became the home of Viticola Toscana, a company that champions the winemaking traditions of the Chianti subzone of Gaiole. And this wine is classic Tuscany: a Chianti made from Sangiovese grapes in the 'Classico' foothills. Expect complex notes of cherry, flowers and vanilla. Serve now with leg of lamb or cellar for another five years.
column9: Black Cherry, Red Fruit, Spice, Strawberry

column1: Guidalberto 2020/21 Tenuta San Guido, IGT Toscana
column2: This wine is a blend of Cabernet Sauvignon and Merlot, and is the 'little brother' to the winery's celebrated Sassicaia, from three vineyard sites surrounding Bolgheri. The varieties are vinified separately before blending and maturation in French and American oak. The wine has an intense violet colour and a soft and rounded fruit profile, and can be enjoyed immediately or over the next 3-4 years.
column9: Vanilla, Black Plum, Blackberry, Earth, Leather, Smoke

column2: The La Serena estate is just nine hectares. But what you'll find there is excellent an organic  Brunello. It's soft and balanced, with flavours of black fruit and spice. Decant for an hour and serve at room temperature with a roast leg of lamb. Drink now.
column9: Vanilla, Earth, Leather, Red Cherry, Red Fruit, Tobacco

column2: You'll find Ornellaia in one of the world’s most exciting wine regions, Bolgheri. They create one of Italy's most in demand wines. This, their second wine, is made on the same estate, with the same attention to detail, and exactly the same practices, but from slightly younger vines. It's your chance to taste their excellence at a reasonable price. A true Super Tuscan. It’s a blend of Cabernet Sauvignon, Merlot, Cabernet Franc and Petit Verdot with depths of flavour and excellent ageing potential.
column6: Petit Verdot, Cabernet Franc, Cabernet Sauvignon

column1: Tenuta San Giorgio ‘Ugolforte’ Brunello di Montalcino DOCG 2016/17
column2: Overlooking the Orcia Valley, with cooling Mediterranean breezes coming in from the west, the Tenuta San Giorgio estate is undeniably picturesque. But its Sangiovese-based wines are even more impressive. This vibrant, rich Brunello di Montalcino is drinkable now, but has potential for future aging, too. Expect aromas of wild strawberry, mint and wood, and a velvety texture with dark-fruit flavours. Try it with grilled meats, truffle-laced pasta or hearty game dishes.
column9: Black Cherry, Blueberry, Charred Wood, Coffee, Red Fruit, Violet

column2: If you're looking for a pure expression of everything great about Tuscan wine, look no further than Buontalenti. Located to the west of the prestigious Chianti region, this family-owned winery only buys from growers they've known for decades. As you'd expect, this wine is a classic Super Tuscan blend of Sangiovese, Merlot and Cabernet Sauvignon. It has bright red and black fruit aromas, with elegant hints of spice and succulent tannins from oak-ageing. We can't think of a better partner for braised lamb.

column1: Vino Nobile Di Montepuliciano 2017/18 Bonacchi, Italy
column2: Don't confuse this Montepulicano with the grape of the same name - this is one of Italys best kept secrets. It's made by one of Tuscany's most exciting up-and-coming winemakers, Ivan Misuri. It's clean and intense, with notes of red fruits, vanilla and spice and a touch of oak. Pair it with grilled meat, aged cheeses or game.

So what’s a Riserva? In Chianti Classico, it must be aged for at least two years in oak barrels, plus three months in the bottle. It takes a lot of patience. But this means it’s more elegant and smooth. Taste the benefits in this release from Villa Antinori. It has aromas of wild cherries and cinnamon and a long, spicy finish. Try it with roasted vegetables.
column9: Vanilla, Cloves, Earth, Red Cherry, Red Fruit, Spice

column2: In the innovative style of the Super-Tuscans, but at a fraction of their price, this is a 'Baby-Tuscan'. Cabernet Sauvignon is blended with a majority of the native Sangiovese to create a wine superior to its IGT classification. Soft and intensely fruity, this wine combines the elegance and complexity given by oak-ageing with the fragrant, fresh fruit of a young wine. Soft on the palate with a smooth finish. A great all-rounder, this wine will complement a rich Tuscan stew, as well as cold cut meats or even just with pizza. This wine won a silver Decanter award for the 2020 vintage.

Despite the label, you can consider this bottle to be a Chianti Rufina Reserva DOCG – Chianti’s most northerly subzone – and the area renowned for making the region’s most long lived wines. Sat in the foothills of the Apennine mountains, vines here benefit from warm sunny days followed by cool nights. The huge changes in temperature results in wines with intense aromas and plenty of fresh acidity – and it’s this acidity that gives them their lengthy ageing potential. Due to a change in production rules in the 1980s, the prestigious Grato family can’t label this bottling a Chianti Rufina. They keep back some of their best cuvées, ageing them for longer than the DOCG panel allows. It means they become what's known as a declassified wine, but don’t let that fool you into thinking this is anything less than a first-rate Tuscan red. Predominantly Sangiovese, the blend spent 30 months in oak barrels, followed by further ageing in tank and bottle before release. Discover intense notes of ripe black cherry and forest floor, with hints of cinnamon spice and leather. It has a silky and savoury character with mellowed tannins, making it a delicious choice for roasted game.

Antinori have been making wine for six centuries. For a whopping 26 generations, this family has produced some of the most celebrated wines throughout central Italy, including this – Tuscany’s iconic Tiganello. It was one of the first 'Super Tuscans', back in the 1970s, that blended traditional with untraditional grape varieties. It's made primarily with Sangiovese, plus Cabernet Sauvignon and Cabernet Franc, and is now one of Italy’s most sought-after wines. It's just as impressive when you crack it open. It's remarkably complex, with aromas of cherry, vanilla, mint and white pepper. There’s a velvety plushness, but freshness, too, so it feels both elegant and rich. Serve with a no-holds-barred special occasion meal: filet mignon with black truffle, for example.
column9: Vanilla, Blackberry, Chocolate, Red Fruit, Spice

column1: Gianni Brunelli Brunello di Montalcino DOCG 2016/17
column2: In 1987, Gianni Brunelli returned home to Montalcino and bought back a property once owned by his father. This, along with a second 4.5 hectare plot of land, very soon became the source of some of the region's most celebrated Brunello. Both estates are now in the hands of his wife, Laura, who upholds the great reputation. This is a concentrated and slightly savoury expression of the Sangiovese grape, with flavours of cherry, wild strawberry, forest floor and tobacco. Decant for an hour before serving with a herby steak of cellar until 2040.
column9: Earth, Leather, Red Cherry, Red Fruit, Tobacco, Vanilla

column2: The Grattamacco estate was founded in Bolgheri in 1977. It was part of the 'Super Tuscan' movement that experimented with blending non-indigenous grapes with Sangiovese. Today, Super Tuscans are some of the most in-demand wines in the world. The team at this estate have been continuously improving the Rosso over more than 38 years – and their expertise really shows. This blend of Cabernet Sauvignon, Cabernet Franc, Merlot and Sangiovese is remarkably drinkable in its youth. It’s a dense, powerful wine with ripe tannins, aromas of dark fruits and chocolate and an excellent structure. Pair it with a hearty Tuscan stew.

column1: La Màgia Organic Brunello di Montalcino DOCG 2016/17
column2: This Brunello has an excellent balance of power, structure and elegance. It was aged for three years in oak on the La Màgia estate, which was orginally a resting place for wayfarers on an old Roman road. Expect notes of red berries, mineral overtones, delicate hints of spice, a balancing acidity, smooth tannins and a long finish.

In Scansano, in the southern part of Tuscany, Morellino is the local name for Sangiovese. In this case blended with 15% Ciliegiolo, another indigenous local grape, this is a slim and youthful style of red, with only a third of the blend spending 6-8 months in new oak. Ripe cherry and strawberry fruit forms the backbone of this wine, which is medium-bodied and approachable, and fresh in feel. A subtly rustic streak gives a touch of complexity and food friendliness. Partner with anything from lamb chops to game, either immediately or within the next 5 years.

If you like Soave, that fresh northern Italian white wine, you're in for a treat with Pieropan. They’re practically synonymous. Pieropan have been producing great wines in Veneto since the 1890s and were the first to use the Soave name on their bottles. Calvarino, their first single-vineyard Soave, debuted in 1971, and its delicious, mineral character is part of what has cemented Pieropan to world-renowned status today. 30-to-60-year-old Garganega and Trebbiano vines produce a well-balanced, elegant wine with aromas of honey, almond, citrus and white flowers. With such a long finish, it can pair brilliantly with all kinds of dishes, including seafood, light pastas and roast chicken.
Dry and possessing a velvety softness this is an ideal food wine. Pair the cherry flavours with herb infused pasta and lamb dishes.

column1: San Leonino 'Al Limite' Chianti Classico DOCG 2018, Half Bottle
column2: San Leonino are serious about Sangiovese. They've focused almost solely on the grape for the past decade. As a result, this 100% Sangiovese half bottle contains all of the characteristic restraint and elegance that you'd expect from only the very best Chianti Classico. It's deep and aromatic with silky flavours of ripe cherries, violets, tobacco and menthol. It's rich enough now to stand up mature cheeses. But it'll continue to improve over the next ten years.
column9: Earth, Red Cherry, Red Fruit, Spice

column2: San Polo is one of the rising-star estates in Italy’s iconic Montalcino region. It has high-altitude vineyards – making for its signature elegant, fresh wines. Its owned by Marilisa Allegrini, who is highly regarded for Amarone, and has been certified by the CasaClima organisation as sustainable since 2013. This is a excellent style of modern-day Brunello. It's rich and cedary, with aromas of violets and red berries and flavours of vanilla and coffee. It has been aged for 30 months in oak and six months in the bottle. This makes for indulgently smooth tannins which are fantastic with roast leg of lamb.
column9: Earth, Leather, Red Cherry, Red Fruit, Tobacco, Vanilla

column2: Sassicaia is widely acknowledged as one of the world's finest Cabernet-based wines. It made history as the first single wine to be granted it's own DOC. A true Super Tuscan. Expect aromas of exotic spice, baked plum, cherry, tobacco and liquorice. Drink 2022-2032, decant for at least two hours before serving and pair with cold-cut meats.

Family-owned Casal Farneto are true champions of Verdicchio, producing more than a dozen different wines from this local white variety. ‘Gran Casale’ means ‘big farmhouse’ and is a nod to the ancient structure from which the winery was built. They work sustainably and organically over 35 acres, employing modern technology where appropriate. The estate is in the province of Ancona, on the border of two valleys, Valmisa and Vallesina. Structure and elegance meet citrus and peach notes – and a light yeasty kick. The team get it just right by harvesting late, in the second half of October, when grape clusters are fully ripe. The result is a fabulous full-bodied white that will match creamy fish dishes perfectly.

column1: Saladini Pilastri Organic Pecorino 2021/22, Offida DOCG
column2: Aromatic Pecorino is a centuries-old Italian grape. Its home is in the rolling hills of Marche and Abruzzo, close to the Adriatic Sea. Nestled in the borders of these regions sits Offida DOCG – here is where you’ll find the cream of the crop. Saladini Pilastri were one of the first winemaking estates in Italy to convert to organic farming. If you haven’t tried Pecorino before, this fantastic bottle is deserving of a place in your collection alongside Gavi and Sauvignon Blanc. It’s bright and full of character, with notes of citrus, white peach, pear and tropical fruit. The energising minerality makes it a wonderfully refreshing wine. Try it with soft cheeses.

column1: Monte Schiavo Organic Verdicchio dei Castelli di Jesi DOC 2022
column2: Italy’s central Marche region is Verdicchio’s spiritual homeland. The grape has been documented here since the 14th century. It’s said that Venetian grapegrowers brought it with them upon fleeing to the countryside during the Plague. Between the Apennine Mountains and the Adriatic Sea, cool and breezy hillsides offer the perfect environment for citrusy, high-acidity Verdicchio. Wines from the high-altitude Castelli di Jesi appellation are known for their refreshing, minerally character. If you’re a fan of Gavi or Chablis, this organic bottling makes a fantastic alternative choice. It’s versatile thanks to rich, zesty flavours and crisp acidity. So pair notes of stone fruits, pineapple and citrus with everything from hard cheeses to fish pie.

column1: Nals Margreid 'Stella Alpina' Pinot Grigio 2021/22, Alto Adige DOC
column2: Alto Adige is in the far North of Italy, with vineyards lining either side of the valley formed by the River Adige. The reputation for quality, particularly from its aromatic white wine, is typified by this high end Pinot Grigio from one of the region's better producers. This is in a different league to entry-level Italian Pinot Grigio, balancing a rich, pure palate of peach, melon and pear fruit with the crispest of finishes. This wine will marry well with fresh tomato salads and seafood dishes such as grilled sea bass or barbecued king prawns.

The Italian classic. Aperol’s distinctive bittersweet flavour is thanks to its unique infusion of rhubarb, orange and herbs. This is a top-secret recipe that hasn’t changed since 1919. It's bright and bittersweet and will blend perfectly with Prosecco for a fresh Aperol spritz.
Ruby red colour, enhanced scents of fresh red fuits, typical of Grasparossa grapes. Delicate and aromatic taste with a bright violet froth.

When it comes to classic Italian fizz, La Gioiosa is a name you can rely on for quality. They're behind some of the most popular bottles in our Prosecco collection, and they bring all the same expertise to this vibrant sparkling wine. It's made in the same style as their signature Prosecco, but with a different blend of white grapes. You'll find it fresh and fruity with crisp apple and pear flavours. The perfect apéritif for any occasion.
Moscato is one of the few grapes that actually tastes of grapes once it is made into wine. This delightful, light and fresh example also possesses floral and honeyed notes.

Have you tried a wine made on a volcano before? This is made on Europe's most active one, Mount Etna. The fifth-generation winemaker behind it creates it from Nerello Mascalese and Nerello Cappuccio grapes. And these varieties really excel in these volcanic soils at this high altitude. As a result, this is an elegant, light red wine, with notes of cherry and redcurrant. Think Nebbiolo meets Pinot Noir. Fantastic with pasta and Parmigiano Reggiano.

The Moretti Polegato family have been making Prosecco for three generations. And this is their cream-of-the-crop fizz. Conegliano Valdobbiadene DOCG is Prosecco's version of a Grand Cru. These rolling hills are where you'll find the very best of the region’s sparkling wine. So if you're going to pick just one bottle, make it this. Expect a soft, creamy mousse with elegant notes of apple, stone fruit and blossom. It’s fantastic with salmon.
column9: Pear, Citrus Fruit, Floral, Green Apple

column1: La Marca Extra Dry Prosecco, Conegliano Valdobbiadene DOCG
column2: This is Prosecco – but better. Conegliano Valdobbiadene DOCG is like Prosecco’s ‘Grand Cru’, and in these hills it’s impossible to cut corners. The vineyards are incredibly steep, so much so that everything has to be done by hand – often with the help of a harness. It’s truly extreme winemaking. But it’s worth it to make fizz this good. Fresh. Floral. Fruity. It has a soft, creamy mousse, with full flavours of ripe white peach, apple and citrus. It’s not bone dry so it’s a great choice as an aperitif.
column9: Pear, Citrus Fruit, Floral, Green Apple

column1: Maschio Conegliano Extra Dry Prosecco Superiore DOCG
column2: There’s Prosecco – and then there’s Prosecco DOCG. The addition of those four little letters signify a big difference. ‘Denomination of Controlled and Guaranteed Origin’ indicates the top tier of quality for Italian wines. Cantine Maschio has been making wine in Veneto’s prestigious Conegliano region since the 1970s. Today the winemaking is led by Gabriele Cescon, who ensures their prize Glera grapes are handled with the utmost care. Only free-run juice is used to make this wine (where grapes are naturally crushed under their own weight in the press). This is considered to be the highest quality juice, since there’s minimal contact with the bitter elements of the grapes. The end result is delicate and refreshing with lively aromas. Extra Dry means it’s not as dry as the Brut style. So if you like particularly fruity Prosecco, this will be right up your street. Fresh. Fruity. Elegant. It has a soft mousse with notes of candied lemon and acacia flowers.

This organic wine is grown in a rural Italian paradise. Vines grow between orchards, elderflower and acacia trees, all teeming with wildlife. This beautiful landscape sets the scene for the Rossi Cairo family’s biodynamic winemaking, which brings purity to all of their wines. Their Gavi embodies this. A zingy blend of fruit and freshness with notes of peach, almond and blossom. Enjoy with fresh pesto pasta.
column9: Lime, Citrus Fruit, Floral, Green Apple, Lemon

column2: We sent our award-winning buying team all around the world on an exciting new mission: to curate a new collection showcasing the best examples of key regions and core grape varietals – at great prices. It’s no secret that Prosecco is extremely popular in the UK. So when we set off to find one that delivered incredible flavour at incredible value for money, we had to go to the experts. This Prosecco hails from a family winery with the youngest owners in the esteemed area of Conegliano Valdobbiadene Prosecco Superiore. It’s where some of the best Prosecco is made – and this is no different. Designed to be fresh, fruity and extremely easy drinking, it’s fully vegan and the ideal bottle to open at parties. Light and elegant, this has fresh notes of apple and pear that make it great as an apéritif or with light fish dishes.

The Definition range brings the world's greatest wine styles to Majestic customers. We tasked our buyers with finding the definition of Gavi di Gavi. They searched the hillside vineyards of Piedmont, a prestigious area where the landscape is dominated by the majestic Alps. This wine comes from the vineyards within the town of Gavi itself, where the Cortese grape ripens slowly thanks to the altitude and cool sea breezes. It’s a fresh, citrusy, food-friendly wine with flavours of ripe apple, lemon peel and a hint of almond with a long concentrated finish. It’s renowned for its ability to pair with food and its crisp flavours work brilliantly with seafood risotto.

column1: La Toledana Gavi di Gavi DOCG 2021
column2: Gian Battista Cambiaso planted the very first Cortese vines in Gavi 400 years ago. The dry white wine he produced was the first recorded in the region, and his Castello La Toledana is one of the very few Genoese noble houses still standing today. Bordering the coastal region of Liguria, their Cortese grapes are cooled by sea breezes and develop mouth-watering flavours. Gavi is often called the ‘Chablis of Italy’, and we can see why. Crisp. Fresh. Citrusy. It’s deliciously refreshing and aromatic, with hints of white peach and honey. Unsurprisingly, given where it’s from, Gavi is fantastic with pesto and vegetable dishes.
column9: Lime, Citrus Fruit, Floral, Green Apple, Lemon

column2: This fresh and fragrant Prosecco is made exclusively for Majestic. The perfect union of flavour and value, this delicious fizz will transport you to the picturesque streets of Venice and its traditional bàcari. Expect lively bubbles and delicate flavours of apple and pear. Enjoy it in classic Italian spritz cocktails, or as an apéritif on a sunny afternoon.

column1: Pasqua 'Romeo & Juliet' Brut Prosecco DOC, Treviso
column2: Verona is the hub of the Veneto region, where vines surround the lakes. Prosecco is the region’s lifeblood – and this deliciously soft, fruity fizz celebrates the romantic legend which draws visitors to Verona. Lovers leave messages in the courtyard of ‘Juliet’s house’ – which also decorate this wine’s label. Bubbles with such a charming story will always make a great centrepiece at parties. Light. Aromatic. Fruity. It’s full of citrus, apple and pear flavours, with a soft mousse.

column1: Roberto Sarotto 'Campo dell'Olio' Gavi di Gavi DOCG 2021/22
column2: The Sarotto family settled in Piedmont in the 1800s, and Roberto is the latest generation to turn his hand to this historic winemaking region. This is his interpretation of the region's iconic white wine, known as The Chablis of Italy, Gavi di Gavi. It's made from 100% Cortese grapes on a 2-hectare vineyard and went through a long, cool fermentation process to draw out the grape's signature aromatics. Add a further three months resting on lees, and you're in for a seriously textured wine. Expect floral notes, with hints of pineapple, apricot and peach. Try it with fish tacos.
column9: Citrus Fruit, Green Apple, Stone Fruit, Wet Stones

column1: Cantine Maschio Extra Dry Prosecco DOC
column2: Cantine Maschio has been making internationally celebrated Prosecco since the 1970s. Bonaventura Maschio turned his family’s century-old distillery into a state-of-the-art winery, capable of producing exceptional fizz. Winemaker Gabriele Cescon ensures their prized Glera grapes are handled with the utmost care. She prefers to use ‘free-run juice’ – high-quality liquid produced when grapes are naturally crushed under their own weight. It means minimal contact with bitter compounds, resulting in elegant wines with pure, fresh flavours. Extra Dry means it’s not as dry as the Brut style – so if you like particularly fruity Prosecco, this will be right up your street. Expect fresh notes of white peach, orange blossom and almond. Best paired with fruity desserts or served as part of a range of cocktails.

Barolo is one of Italy's most highly regarded fine-wine styles – with prices that match its stellar reputation. But if you find the right producer, you can still taste something fantastic in the region that doesn't break the bank. Ciabot Berton is a relatively small winery run by brother-and-sister team of Marco and Paola Oberto. They make this wine from a number of vineyards in the celebrated La Morra commune and age it in oak for two years. It's elegant and full-bodied, with aromas of roses, truffle, blackcurrant and cinnamon. Try it with venison stew.
column9: Spice, Earth, Leather, Red Fruit, Rose

column2: The Definition range brings the world's greatest wine styles to Majestic customers. Barolo is one of Italy's most iconic wines. To some, it is the very best. To capture the very best elements of it, we went to a family-run company who are considered local pioneers in the region. They didn't take the task lightly. This is aged for at least 24 months before release. As a result, it's intense and wonderfully aromatic, with notes of red fruits and creamy oak and silk-smooth tannins. Try it with game birds or a roast dinner.

When it comes to lavish, supple reds that partner beautifully with richly-flavoured food you needn't look further than Italy. Indulge in Araldica Barbera's cocoa-and-spice-stroked palate of red cherry and dried fruit.
column9: Sweet Spice, Red Cherry, Red Plum, Spice

column2: In the belief that the best Barolo's delicate and aromatic, Araldica rests its this for at least two years in oak and another in the bottle. It's not until four years after the harvest has finished that this is released. Taste the benefits of patience in a full-bodied palate that's chock full of rich red fruits, sweet spices, a balancing earthiness and a brooding hint of smoke.

The De Forville domaine covers ten hectares over two Piedmont villages and their production is now almost entirely bottled on the estate. Nebbiolo is a Piedmont stalwart and most famous for its role in Barolo. A Nebbiolo with striking ruby colour and a nose that displays bright red fruits with hints of spice. This complexity is carried onto the palate with racy acidity and oak bringing freshness and structure. The soft tannins make this wine a viable option to open now. Give it time in the decanter and serve with fatty meats or creamy cheese.

column1: Marcarini Barolo del Comune di La Morra 2017/18, Italy
column2: Barolo is widely considered Italy's king of wines. Head to the region, and you'll find the dark depths of Poderi Marcarini's winery. They may not make for an enticing holiday destination, but this wine is protected from light and temperature changes while ageing there. This means it can evolve and mature to its best without disruption, perfecting the powerful aromas and preserving unique flavours. The result is a rich, fresh bouquet of violets and roses and a long, intense finish.

The Pio Cesare winery has gained fame around the world since it began in 1881. Today, their exceptional wines are found in high-class restaurants and hotels around the world. Their Barbaresco is subtle and silky, with notes of wild berries, white liquorice and a hint of oak. Decant for at least an hour before serving at room temperature with steak tartare.

Barbaresco is the less tannic sibling of Barolo. The wine here is also made from the Nebbiolo grape, but typically aged for a shorter period. The pioneering family behind Roberto Sarotto make it on a single vineyard called Currà. It's complex, refined and smooth, with hints of roses, violet, plum, liquorice and chocolate. It was aged for two and a half years, so it's a harmonious wine that compliments red meats excellently.

The Voerzio brothers were part of the Barolo Boys, an iconic generation of winemakers that changed the world of Barolo wine. Gianni Voerzio's son, Mirko, today continues with their work. To create the most concentrated Barolo, he strictly limits the yields in the vineyard, allowing just 1kg of grapes per vine. It's no-expense-spared winemaking, and the benefits show in this bottle. Expect notes of plum, blackberry, spice and dried herbs and silk-smooth tannins, thanks to a very long ageing process. Drink now with grilled lamb, or cellar it for another 10 years. Monica Lamer gave the 2017 vintage 92 Parker Points.

Pasqua has been producing excellent Italian wine since 1925. Unlike many sweeter supermarket bottles, their Prosecco is made in a dry style, resulting in elegant, velvet-smooth bubbles. This is a delicious rosé take on their ever-popular Romeo & Juliet Prosecco. To make it, they've included a portion of Pinot Noir grapes. It’s fresh and lively with lush raspberry notes.
column9: Citrus Fruit, Red Fruit, Stone Fruit

column2: Up until the end of 2020, producers weren't allowed to label rosé fizz as Prosecco – even if it was made inside the designated regions and to the same high standards as the classic white bubbles. But labelling laws have finally changed. And we're thrilled to be stocking one of the first rosé Proseccos to hit UK shelves. Best of all, it's made by Prosecco experts, La Gioiosa. Dry, fresh and zesty, with notes of redcurrants and raspberries, and a lovely floral quality. It's seriously moreish and perfect with raspberry soufflé.
column9: Strawberry, Citrus Fruit, Raspberry, Red Fruit

column2: In the world of wine and grappa, Bottega’s history spans four centuries. The passion and dedication that goes into their bottlings is clear – but how do they taste? The estate’s drinks range has received more than 350 awards worldwide, so you can be sure you’re picking up more than just a pretty bottle. This sparkling rosé is made from Lombardy’s finest Pinot Nero – the Italian name for Pinot Noir. Expect intense floral and fruity aromas with flavours of wild summer berries with a long, refreshing finish.
column9: Citrus Fruit, Honey, Raspberry, Red Apple, Strawberry

column2: Prosecco is to Venice what pork pies are to Melton Mowbry. It’s part of the city’s identity. Venetians are just crazy about Prosecco – but not just any old fizz. They know the good stuff when they taste it, and they demand the very best. Our buyers tasted countless Proseccos to try and find the perfect union of flavour and value, but we couldn’t quite find what we were looking for. So, we decided to commission it. Aqualta was the result, made exclusively for us – and we think it’s the perfect Prosecco. It’s fragrant with really delicate aromas of apple and pear. The style’s typical of the super-fresh fizz served in backstreet bàcari; used to top up Venice’s signature spritzes, or chase a groaning table of cichèti. It’s a mouthwatering slice of Italy at home. Great flavour. Great value. Great fizz. What more could you need?

Once you’ve seen a bottle of Bottega fizz, it’s not easily forgotten. But there’s more than a touch of glamour behind these wines. This legendary estate dates back all the way to the 17th century, when Andrea Bottega began cultivating vines high in the Treviso hills. Fast forward to today and the sustainably run family estate is now world-renowned for its award-winning Prosecco, grappa and gin. Bottega Gold is made from grapes in Valdobbiadene – the area recognised for producing the finest Prosecco. It even took gold at The Drinks Business Prosecco Masters 2021. So you can rest assured that this eye-catching bottle is not style over substance. Expect orchard fruit, citrus and floral aromas, a soft, refreshing mousse, and a touch of spice on the finish.
