column1: Tenuta Olim Bauda ‘Era’ Barbera D’Asti DOCG 2019
column2: Northern Italy is a fantastic area for showstopping red wines, but it’s the more bold styles, like Amarone, that often grab the headlines. For a more vibrant, youthful take on Italian reds, Barbera is not to be missed. Tenuta Olim Bauda forgoes the use of oak entirely in the making of this wine. The result? A fresh, fruit-forward style of Barbera with plenty of delicious unfiltered character and aromas of black cherry, chocolate and sweet spice. Try it with beef in teryaki sauce.

Until recently, producers weren't allowed to label sparkling rosé as 'Prosecco' – even if it was made inside the region and to the same standard as the traditional white bubbles. Labelling laws have finally changed. Our buyers tasted countless examples to try and find the very best at great value. We had this custom-made by a trusted producer – and we think it's the perfect easy-sipping fizz. It's delicate and fresh, with fruity aromas of apple, citrus and raspberry.

Nebbiolo takes it name from 'nebbia', the fog cloaking the hills of Piedmont around harvest time. The village of Barbaresco lies only a little to the north-east of Barolo in Piedmont and produces wines of a similar style and quality. A big, elegant wine of pale colour. Dark cherries and leather with earthy hints, and a rose perfume, a charming, well integrated wine with a long finish. Muscular tannins give the wine a solid backbone. Try this with a fillet steak with mushrooms. The wine will nicely echo the earthy notes of the mushrooms.

Barbera is a prolific Italian grape variety grown in Piedmont and particularly around the towns of Alba and Asti. This Barbera d'Alba is made by the excellent De Forville family using fruit from over 40 years old vines. Very concentrated dark fruits on the nose, with well integrated spices. This exhibits confected dark cherry fruits with hints of chocolate, cloves and vanilla. Well integrated and silky smooth finish. Meat dishes with grilled vegetables will complement this wine superbly.
column9: Sweet Spice, Earth, Red Cherry, Red Plum

column2: One of the lesser-known grapes of Piedmont, Dolcetto usually produces soft, fruity and early maturing wines. The best come from around Alba, as does this one from De Forville, a family that has been making wine in Piedmont since the 1860's. A clear and bright ruby in colour, with an expressive nose of youthful fruits. Rich, dark cherries and liquorice on the palate and a fresh finish. Enjoy with cold cuts or cured meats, pizza, or on its own.

‘Sustainable’ and ‘organic’ may be buzzwords today, but the Vajra family has been championing both in Piedmont ever since the 1970s. At their vineyards, biodiversity is encouraged, whether it’s allowing grass to sprout in between rows of vineyards or birds to nest in the nearby forest. Huge amounts of manual work are put into producing each vintage of this excellent Barolo, which is made from 100% Nebbiolo grapes. It has aromas of redcurrant, strawberries and cherries and floral hints of rosebud and black fig. Try it with sausage tagliatelle.

Barolo may hog the limelight, but the larger region of Langhe in which it sits is home to some equally impressive Nebbiolo wines. Pio Cesare’s Barolo is world-renowned – and they pay just as much care and attention to this wine as their most sought-after bottles. Grapes are carefully hand-picked – including some from their highly-regarded Barolo and Barbaresco vineyards. The wine is then aged in oak for 24 months, creating a full-bodied, savoury red. It’s remarkably fresh, with intense notes of ripe and juicy red fruits. Rich roast lamb will balance its firm tannins perfectly.

Pecorino is an early ripening, thin-skinned grape, native to central parts of Italy. The bunches tend to be very triangular in shape, reminiscent of a sheep's head, said to be the reason for the grape's name. Pale yellow, with a remarkably intense nose of citrus fruits, hints of hawthorn and orange blossom. Soft, clean, but persistent palate texture, with a pleasing mineral complexity. Try with nutty cheeses, such as the wine's sheep's milk cheese namesake, or with simple cod dishes.
column9: Lemon, Blossom, Citrus Fruit, Green Apple

column2: ''Ammazza translates as wow and that is what this wine does with its heady cherry flavours and extra body.  This is a modern take on traditional Italian reds - bold, characterful and  full of flavour.'' Great to drink on its own, but a secret to drinking Italian ... it's all about the food. Try with your mid-week pizza, or any other tomato based dishes.

column1: Ammazza Pinot Grigio 2020/21, Terre di Chieti IGT
column2: Delle Venezie is famous for its Pinot Grigios – and three years ago, it was awarded DOC status to protect the quality of its wines, and to show the world exactly how delicious Pinot Grigio can be. DOC stands for Denominazione di Origine Controllata – and it means that wines here have a quality guarantee. This wine is a case in point. Zippy. Citrussy. Crisp. It’s a seriously refreshing glassful, full of zesty citrus flavours. It’s lemony. It’s refreshing. It’s got a lovely peach and white-blossom flavours too. Such a delicious Pinot Grigio makes a fantastic aperitif, but it’s also fantastic with salads.

Abruzzo has seriously strict rules. And you can really taste the quality in this. It's a step up from other Montepulciano, boasing notes of ripe cherries, sweet spices and an alluring hint of smoke. It's comfort food in a bottle.

Chieti in Abruzzo is one of the largest wine-producing provinces in Italy. Codice Citra was established in the 1970s with quality, not quantity in mind. Grapes are estate-grown and bottled from a collection of just 9 family-owned vineyards. Vines thrive in this area thanks to the unique climate. Warm winds blow in from the Adriatic sea, meeting the cooler air flowing down from the Majela mountains. The locals refer to the resulting valley breeze as ‘brezza di terra’ – and it’s this that encourages perfect grape ripening. This is a beautifully floral, refreshing wine with stone fruit and citrus flavours. It’s excellent with fresh white fish and a squeeze of lemon.

Chieti in Abruzzo is one of the largest wine-producing provinces in Italy. Codice Citra was established in the 1970s with quality, not quantity in mind. Grapes are estate-grown and bottled from a collection of just 9 family-owned vineyards. Vines thrive in this area thanks to the unique climate. Warm winds blow in from the Adriatic sea, meeting the cooler air flowing down from the Majela mountains. The locals refer to the resulting valley breeze as ‘brezza di terra’ – and it’s this that encourages perfect grape ripening. This blend of local grape varieties is bold and juicy. There’s a delicate note of violet alongside ripe cherry, and soft tannins on the finish. It’s fantastic with roast lamb.

Family-owned Tommasi has significant vineyard holdings in Valpolicella Classico but also in Lugana, on the shores of Lake Garda. This rosé, a blend of gently pressed Turbiana and Rondinella grapes, hails from the latter. Head winemaker and family member Giancarlo Tommasi carefully vinifies the wine at controlled temperatures in stainless steel, creating a pale pink bottling with rich aromas of grapefruit, peach blossom and mandarin zest. The flavour is equally vibrant, with a fresh, citrussy acidity and a persistent finish. Try it as an aperitif with canapes or (what else?) a pizza.

Nunzio Ghiraldi Snr sold his delicious grapes off only to watch a famous winery pick up the credit for decades. Not anymore. Twenty years ago, Nunzio Jnr used the vines originally planted by his grandfather to make this dry white wine from the indigenous Turbiana grape. It's fruity and elegant, with notes of almond, peach, apricot and flint, a generous acidity and an excellent length.

column1: Cantina Chiara Ziliani 'Duca Diseo' Franciacorta DOCG Brut
column2: Franciacorta is Italy's answer to Champagne. To achieve the same high quality, sparkling wines here are produced using the traditional second-fermentation method applied in the prestigious French region. And much like in Champagne, winemaker Chiara Ziliani ensures only the best Pinot Noir and Chardonnay grapes are carefully harvested by hand for her blend. Luxurious and complex, it’s aged in contact with the residual yeast sediment known as ‘lees’, giving it a delicious creamy texture. Expect aromas of white peach, apple and pear and rich bread and biscuit flavours. It’s a perfect match for seafood risotto.

Vermentino is the gem of the island of Sardinia. Because it's still relatively unknown, you can find great value with the grape. Like this expression from Eccelsa. It's made by a family whose wines top tables in the best Italian restaurants. It's intense and aromatic, with notes of summer fruits. Excellent with seafood.
